expanded_description: Exponential decay occurs when a quantity decreases by the same factor over equal time intervals. Unlike linear decay, which subtracts the same amount each time, exponential decay multiplies by the same factor less than 1. This models many natural phenomena including radioactive decay, drug concentration in the body, and depreciation of assets.

core_concept.principle:
An exponential decay function has the form $y = a(1 - r)^t$ or $y = ab^t$ where:
• $a$ is the initial amount (when $t = 0$)
• $r$ is the decay rate (as a decimal)
• $b = 1 - r$ is the decay factor (between 0 and 1)
• $t$ is time (or number of periods)
• $y$ is the amount after $t$ periods
core_concept.explanation: Think of exponential decay like the way a medicine leaves your body. If a drug has a half-life of 4 hours, after 4 hours half remains, after 8 hours one-quarter remains, and so on. The amount decreases by the same fraction each time period, never quite reaching zero but getting closer and closer.

sections.introduction: Exponential decay is characterized by a constant percent decrease over equal time intervals.

introduction_image.alt: Table showing linear vs exponential decay patterns
introduction_image.caption: Figure 9.5.2: Linear subtracts constant; exponential multiplies by constant factor < 1.

key_concept.definition: A quantity decays exponentially if it decreases by the same percentage each time period. This means that to get from one value to the next, you multiply by a constant factor (the decay factor) that is between 0 and 1. For example, 100, 80, 64, 51.2 multiplies by 0.8 each time.
key_concept.context: Recognizing exponential decay patterns helps in choosing the right model for real-world situations involving decrease.

image.alt: Comparison table: linear vs exponential decay
image.caption: Figure 9.5.3: Linear vs exponential decay patterns.

worked_examples.title: Identifying Decay Patterns

image.caption: Figure 9.5.4: Determine if each represents linear or exponential decay.

worked_examples.problem:
Determine whether each sequence represents linear decay (subtracting constant) or exponential decay (multiplying by constant factor < 1):
a) 100, 90, 80, 70, 60
b) 100, 50, 25, 12.5, 6.25
c) 500, 400, 320, 256, 204.8
d) 1000, 800, 600, 400, 200
worked_examples.final_answer: a) Linear, b) Exponential, c) Exponential, d) Linear
worked_examples.concept_applied: Look for constant subtraction (linear) vs constant multiplication (exponential).

sections.introduction: The general form of an exponential decay function is $y = a(1 - r)^t$.

introduction_image.alt: Exponential decay formula with labeled parts
introduction_image.caption: Figure 9.5.6: The exponential decay formula.

key_concept.definition:
In $y = a(1 - r)^t$:
• $a$ = initial amount (when $t = 0$)
• $r$ = decay rate (as a decimal, e.g., 20% = 0.20)
• $b = 1 - r$ = decay factor (must be between 0 and 1 for decay)
• $t$ = time (in appropriate units)
• $y$ = amount after time $t$
key_concept.context: This formula is used whenever something decreases by a constant percentage each period.

worked_examples.title: Writing Exponential Decay Functions

image.caption: Figure 9.5.8: Write an exponential decay function for each situation.

worked_examples.problem:
Write an exponential decay function for each situation:
a) A radioactive substance with 500 grams decays at 10% per year.
b) A car worth $\$25,000$ depreciates at 15% per year.
c) A medicine with 200 mg in the bloodstream decreases by 25% every 4 hours.
d) A population of 10,000 decreases by 3% per year.

step_by_step.explanation: 10% decay rate means r = 0.10, so decay factor = 0.90

worked_examples.concept_applied: For percent decay, decay factor = 1 - r. For non-unit time intervals, use fractional exponents.

sections.introduction: Once we have the function, we can calculate values for specific times by substituting and evaluating.

key_concept.definition: To find the amount after a given time, substitute the time value into the function and evaluate. Remember that the decay factor is less than 1, so values decrease over time.
key_concept.context: These calculations tell us what the quantity will be at future times as it decays.

worked_examples.title: Calculating Future Values
worked_examples.problem:
Use the functions from the previous examples to find:
a) Radioactive material after 5 years: $y = 500(0.90)^t$
b) Car value after 3 years: $y = 25000(0.85)^t$
c) Medicine after 12 hours: $y = 200(0.75)^{t/4}$
d) Population after 10 years: $y = 10000(0.97)^t$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Substitute time and evaluate, using calculator for powers as needed.

sections.introduction: Half-life is the time it takes for an exponentially decaying quantity to reduce to half its initial amount.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 9.5.14: Half-life - time to reduce by half.

key_concept.definition: For exponential decay, the half-life is constant. If a quantity decays by factor $b$ per time unit, the half-life $T$ satisfies $b^T = \frac{1}{2}$, so $T = \frac{\log(1/2)}{\log b} = \frac{-\log 2}{\log b} = \frac{\log 2}{-\log b}$. Since $b < 1$, $\log b$ is negative, making $T$ positive.
key_concept.context: Half-life is commonly used in radioactive decay, medicine, and other decay processes.

image.alt: Example: 20% decay per year means b=0.8, half-life = log(0.5)/log(0.8) ≈ 3.1 years
image.caption: Figure 9.5.15: Half-life calculation.

worked_examples.title: Calculating Half-Life
worked_examples.problem:
Find the half-life for each decay rate:
a) A substance decays at 5% per year.
b) A medicine has a decay factor of 0.75 every 4 hours.
c) A radioactive element decays to 25% of its original amount in 10 years. Find its half-life.

step_by_step.explanation: 25% remaining means two half-lives have passed (50%, then 25%)

worked_examples.final_answer: a) About 13.5 years, b) About 9.64 hours, c) 5 years
worked_examples.concept_applied: Half-life is time to reduce to half; use logarithms to solve when not an integer number of half-lives.

sections.introduction: Sometimes we have data and need to find the decay rate or factor.

key_concept.definition: Given two data points at different times, we can find the decay factor by dividing later value by earlier value (if time difference is 1 unit). For longer intervals, we need to use roots. The decay rate $r$ is then $1 - b$.
key_concept.context: This is useful when we have experimental data and need to model the decay process.

image.alt: Example: From 100 to 80 in 1 year, factor = 0.8, rate = 20%
image.caption: Figure 9.5.19: Finding rate example.

worked_examples.title: Finding Decay Rate

image.caption: Figure 9.5.20: Find the annual decay rate.

worked_examples.problem:
Find the annual decay rate in each situation:
a) A radioactive sample dropped from 100g to 80g in one year.
b) A car's value fell from $\$20,000$ to $\$15,000$ in one year.
c) A substance decayed from 500g to 300g in 3 years (find annual rate).

step_by_step.explanation: Overall factor = $\frac{300}{500} = 0.6$ over 3 years. Annual factor $b$ satisfies $b^3 = 0.6$

worked_examples.concept_applied: Decay factor = later/earlier. Rate = 1 - factor. For multi-period, use roots.

sections.section_title: 9.5.7 Common Errors and How to Avoid Them
sections.introduction: Students often make specific mistakes with exponential decay. Awareness helps prevent these errors.

classifications.value: Using growth factor > 1 for decay, or decay factor < 1 for growth.
characteristics: Not understanding that decay factor must be less than 1

image.caption: Figure 9.5.30: Error - using growth factor for decay.

classifications.value: Using $r$ instead of $1-r$ as the multiplier.
classifications.behavior: Values become far too small too quickly.

examples.process: Error: $y = 100(0.20)^t$ for 80% decay? Actually 20% decay gives factor 0.8, not 0.2

classifications.value: Thinking half-life means the substance disappears after that time.
characteristics: Thinking after one half-life, nothing remains
Not understanding that it keeps halving indefinitely

image.alt: Correct: continues halving vs incorrect: disappears
image.caption: Figure 9.5.32: Error - misinterpreting half-life.

examples.process: Error: After one half-life, all is gone
examples.explanation: Correct: Half remains after one half-life, then half of that, etc.

worked_examples.title: Correcting Decay Errors
worked_examples.problem: A student wrote: 'A car worth $\$20,000$ depreciates 15% per year, so after 3 years it's worth $20000(1.15)^3 = 20000 × 1.52 = 30400$.' Identify and correct the error.

step_by_step.explanation: Student used growth factor 1.15 instead of decay factor 0.85
step_by_step.calculation: 15% depreciation means value retains 85% each year

worked_examples.final_answer: Correct value: $\$12,282.50$. Student used growth instead of decay.
worked_examples.concept_applied: For decay, use factor 1 - r, not 1 + r.

image.caption: Figure 9.5.34: Common errors summary.

summary: Exponential decay occurs when a quantity decreases by a constant percentage over equal time intervals, modeled by $y = a(1-r)^t$ where $a$ is the initial amount, $r$ is the decay rate (as a decimal), and $t$ is time. The decay factor $b = 1-r$ is between 0 and 1. Half-life—the time for a quantity to reduce to half—is constant for exponential decay and can be calculated using logarithms. Real-world applications include radioactive decay (carbon dating), asset depreciation, and drug elimination from the body. When given data, the decay factor can be found by dividing later values by earlier values, and the decay rate is $1 - b$. Exponential decay differs from linear decay in that it multiplies by a constant factor rather than subtracting a constant amount, leading to decreases that are rapid initially but slow over time.
